PPE and medicines are running low MPs to scrutinise how the government awarded billions of pounds worth of contracts to supply personal protective equipment at the height of the pandemic when global PP supplies became scarce team was fond of Whitehall to try to ensure frontline workers receive the equipment they needed the public accounts committee will consider whether there was adequate transparency and value for money more details from our political correspondent Alex Forsyth at the height of the pandemic global demand for PP skyrocketed the government's usual supply chains largely from China with hugely disrupted as pressure from the NHS frontline group the government asked British business to step up and help source or supply PP ram fame manufacturer in the West Midlands was one such firm in 10 days they turn a derelict site into a factory making 3 million face Pfizer's a week Timothy McQueen is the sales director this project alone has created 500 new jobs this is empty 8 weeks ago and look at it today producing this year inspiring ramp fame praised the government's approach saying it delivered vital kit at a crucial time contracts totalling billions of pounds were issued to around 175 Kompany's some were established manufacturers or suppliers of medical equipment but others seemingly had little experience now some government decisions are subject to a legal challenge by the good law project and the public accounts committee has said it will look into the process by which contracts were awarded in the autumn the Labour MP Meg Hillier chairs the committee we're very concerned about the general lack of focus when you are dealing with something at this pace almost inevitably there will be some attempt at forward the key thing is they will be looking at whether government have mechanisms in place to prevent that and crucially to prevent the wrong equipment and not proper equipment being delivered to the front line there was no prerequisite for firms which won contracts to have previous experience in PPE supply the point was to find new sources in a statement the government said over 2.4 billion items have been delivered with billions more in order to ensure a continuous supply a spokesman said there was a robust process in place to ensure orders were high quality and met strict safety standards with due diligence undertaken on all government contracts the national trust has announced 1200 job losses as it expects to lose up to 200 million £ this year as a result of the pandemic the charity's director general Hillary McGrady said the lockdown coupled with the longer term implications of social distancing and suppressed trading meant there was a need for a full review of the organisation's spending and priorities the heads of 4 of the world's biggest technology firms are facing questions at a us congressional hearing investigating whether the stifling competition the inquiry has been looking into FacebookAmazonGoogle and Apple which have a combined stock market value of around 5 trillion $ from more than a year ahead of today's appearance face Looks chief executive Mark Zuckerberg defended the firm's acquisition of WhatsApp and Instagram insisting help them grow Here's our Washington correspondent Barbara Plett-Usher the corporate power and wealth on display is unlike any that US politicians have faced before together FacebookAmazonGoogle and Apple have greater value than the entire German economy they have billions of customers and industry has transformed society they are the 4 horsemen of the Tekapo lips in the words of one commentator but are they are stifling competition with unfair practices this congressional committee has carried out an exhaustive investigation into whether big tech needs to be held to account and this hearing is the climax the Corona virus pandemic means the men are participating remotely ironically underscoring how thoroughly every sector of society has come to depend on other digital platforms each company has a distinct profile in a specific market the antitrust issues they face are complex and different and each tech titan has his own approached but all will argue that they face plenty of competition and that they are good for America that they built their success the American way and continue to encourage us innovation what Congress has to decide is whether new anti-trust laws are needed to oversee the tech giant's or whether the old ones are good enough today's hearing may not clinched the argument either way no doubt there will be plenty of political theatre but the spectacle of a joint hearing could be symbolically important in driving momentum towards greater regulation a man whose allotment is next to the one being searched by German police investigating the disappearance of three-year-old Madeleine McCann claims the main suspect in the case rented the plot the man told the BBC that the 43 year-old German national arrived there in the year Madeleine

the services needed to force the pace of change and to continue to root out racism America's top general has apologised for joining President Trump on widely criticised walk to church in Washington DC earlier this month the staged event took place after authorities forcefully dispersed anti-racism protesters who had gathered there for a largely peaceful demonstration general Mark Milley said his presence had created a perception of military involvement in domestic politics as a commissioning uniformed officer was a mistake but I learned from and I sincerely hope we all can learn from we are aware of the cloth Coronation come from the people of our nation we must hold dear the principle of a political military and so deeply rooted the very essence of our public Amazon has banned all police forces worldwide from using its facial recognition technology for a year the decision follows concerns raised by civil rights advocates particularly in the US about the potential for racial bias in surveillance software Here's our technology correspondent Rory Cellan-Jones facial recognition technology has made huge strides in recent years with much of the innovation coming from China but there's also been growing concern about its use for surveillance by both law enforcement agencies and private companies earlier this week IBM announced that it would no longer offer facial recognition software and concerns that it might be less accurate at identify An African American faces now Amazon says it will stop allowing forces to use its recognition software which can match photos on an officer's smartphone to those on a database of suspects the company said it was imposing a one year moratorium in the hope that Congress would bring in regulations on the ethical use of the technology the analyst Stephanie hare says this is a key moment in the debate Emerson decision is very significant because it's an example of the big tech player putting the ball back in the government's court saying you need to regulate this technology we are voluntarily stepping back from selling it for one year forgiving you know this you got 12 months to regulate it in the UK South Wales police has been an early adopter of facial recognition systems a shopper who took the forced to court lost his bid to get a judicial review of the technology which he said had breached his human rights later this month an appeal against that ruling will be heard police in Northern Ireland have confirmed that a gun found in Londonderry on Saturday was the weapon used in the murder of a journalist last year the key was shot dead during a riot in the city Detectives have said that the discovery is significant Ireland correspondent Chris page reports the euro QE was 29 when she was killed by dissident Republicans who are opposed to the peace process she was shot during Street violence which broke out during a police operation in the Creggan area of Derry the gunman was from a group known as the new IRA last weekend police soldiers find fully primed bomb and a firearm a search for 38 acres of land in the city Detectives nice say the gun recovered was the one which fired the shot that killed Lee Remick key they've described the find as a milestone in a complex investigation the weapon will be examined further to see what forensic evidence can be extracted from it one mum is currently in custody charged with murder the government has scrapped plans to involve private companies in the probation system in England and Wales under the changes announced by the justice secretary Robert Buckland responsibility for the supervision and rehabilitation for released prisoners and those serving community sentences will pass back to the state run National probation service Labour welcomed what it called a U-turn on the privatisation of the system our home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw reports in 2014 the then justice Secretary Chris Grayling overhaul probation by outsourcing the supervision of low and medium risk offenders the part privatisation of the system was beset with problems so last year a new model was announced instead of monitoring offenders private companies would run rehabilitation services under 8 year contracts worth 1.3 billion £ now though the government has abandoned that idea having decided that the entire probation system is better off in the hands of the state Robert Buckland said the National probation service will provide more flexibility and resilience amid uncertainty about caseloads following the Corona virus outbreak at Uber's latest our planet show what they are doing and why the list included day on Radio 4 with Justin Webb and John Humphrys of our art of art art It's 7 o'clock on Monday the 8th of April the News headlines this morning senior managers social media companies could be held personally liable for protecting children and other online users under new government proposals Labour says progress in talks on a cross party Brexit compromise now depends on a concrete offer from the government and a British woman is facing a lengthy prison sentence in Dubai for making insulting remarks about her ex husband on Facebook BBC News is red bandanna speed social media companies could see their services blocked and senior managers held personally liable if the firms breach new statutory duty of care a government white paper published today says companies must take more responsibility for users safety as well as for harmful content that appears on their sites the home Secretary Sajid Javid said tech firms were being forced to clean up their act once and for all the NSPCC said the proposals which are now good consultation will make Britain a world pioneer in protecting children online with the details Here's our media editor Amol Rajan in recent years the big technology firms have come under sustained pressure to act as images of self harm child abuse and terrorist propaganda have permeated through social media platforms this long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations but many of the details remain far from clear for the first time oversight of the internet would be interested to a regulator a statutory duty of care to protect users would be enforced with potential for heavy fines to be administered the government has not yet decided whether it will set up a new regulator or trust this work to an existing watchdog a sure sign that hard policy work is just beginning the new rules will apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user generated content or ought to interact with others critics say apply the same rules the company's of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance so entrenching power of big tech with just days to go before Britain is due to leave the EU without a deal Labour is waiting to learn whether the government will put forward proposals which could break the impasse the Brexit yesterday the Prime Minister defended her decision to seek cross-party compromise but today a leading Brexiteer Boris Johnson warned the getting Labour on board could involve he called completely unacceptable surrender our political correspondent Vicki young reports Theresa may has said a cross-party compromise is now the only way forward because the DUP and some of her own MPs have refused to back her deal some pro-Brexit Conservatives fear the Prime Minister is preparing to keep Britain in the customs union one of Jeremy Corbyn's key demands communication between the two sides is continuing but little detail has emerged Labour figures believe progress now depends on a concrete offer from the government the former foreign Secretary Boris Johnson writing in the Telegraph as a customs union would mean Britain has no control over its trade policy and it cannot must not and will not happen on Wednesday Mrs may will go to Brussels for an emergency EU summit she's already requested another short Brexit delay until the end of June but if EU leaders don't think she has a credible plan to get Parliament behind Deal they might refuse or insist on a much lengthier extension to article 50 and outcome which is also opposed by some Brexiteers with just 5 days to go before the UK is due to leave the EU there are still great uncertainty Let's take a moment to look at their claim that democracy is under threat from misinformation target at us through social media to play on our fears and prejudices That's the conclusion of one of them anything new in this report had a few bike to this story of last month well morning Simon Yeah I think what it does is pull together as a vast sweep of this inquiry which started off looking kind of failure of the fake news phenomenon and zeroed in on the Cambridge Analytica scandal and the behaviour of campaigners during the EU referendum campaign and that there is new detail there is a lot of detail about what Cambridge Analytica was up to and also about aggregate IQ Canadian firm said to be linked to Cambridge Analytica which was a player which was used by the vote leave campaign and separately the the leave campaign during the EU referendum and there are allegations which have been detailed in the in the report about the links between the two of them we saw last week electoral Commission finding that they were linked and finding some of the participants So more evidence on all of that as the underlying all of this there's an assumption that this kind of campaigning this kind of targeted content or adverts actually works and can in every say democracy is under threat you're making assumptions this this these techniques work Yeah well I mean one of the striking things this week was that the the committee published a whole series of adverts placed on Facebook by vote leave and be leave during the 2016 campaign place during the final days before people voted and the point that the committee was making was that these these adverts had not been visible in the way that a billboard diesel or a leaflet posted through your door they were reaching millions of people with their quite strong messages but it wasn't completely clear where they were coming from and is a great call for much no clear transparency in in the way of campaigning works in the digital era the rules not being fit for the digital era OK we will talk to somebody who's an expert in political campaigning and read a book on this very subject get some of the response from the tech sector this recommendation tougher regulation potentially even higher taxes on some of those big tech companies it is 18 minutes past 7 the opportunities Brexit presents to rewrite the rules on farm subsidies will that have a dramatic effect on the way we farm in the UK but even more profound impact may come from a new technological revolutions just gearing up across industry agriculture it may not be long before the autonomous tractors be used today give way to an army of robots that can plant tend to read and harvest our crops crops that will themselves tell the robots what they need and when they're ready to be harvested our science editor Tom Fielden has been down to the farm of the future harvest has come early this year across the country massive got bikes this one the lumbering reader feel it is an impressive machine capable of scything 30 good part time we are you break every hour and as such it represents the pinnacle of a decades long drive to intensified and mechanised farming grinding out increases in productivity through economies of scale farming is not immune to the technological revolution that's transforming so many aspects of modern life the information revolution a big data other side of the mighty corporations big tech the likes of Google and Facebook said these proposals are wrong in principle and unworkable in practice they argue that the filters which they have to apply to material are very expensive to build which could have the unintended consequence of placing even more power in the hands of a few big companies the directive has been through several iterations Emily Wood a lawyer specialising in intellectual property says it probably won't be clear exactly how it's going to work until the first cases are settled in court this directive so what will happen is it will have to go for member States and then how are how widely interpreted enforced will depend on curry paste or how the courts generally interpreted what's at stake here is the very nature of the internet it has already evolved from the libertarian paradise of its founders to an arena dominated by a few mostly Californian corporations it is now evolving again toward a more regulated vision devised in Brussels but stopping short of the walled garden users see in China last week the EU fine Google 1.5 billion euros for anti-competitive behaviour and last year Europe's new data regulations GDPR set a new international standard for consumers as with competition and data so with copyright the future of the web is being written in Brussels rather than Silicon Valley European football's governing body Uefa has opened disciplinary proceedings into racist behaviour during England's match in Montenegro last night the euro Twenty20 qualifier which Gareth Southgate's side won 5 one was marred by racist chants by some home supporters towards England players the Uefa president Aleksander Ceferin said that the abuse was a disaster and the campaign group kick it out said Montenegro should be expelled from the competition Our sports editor Dan Roan has this assessment I feel very uncomfortable for a good feeling that here is a racial chanting already when Dani Alves is ticking before that far side on the field the this was another hugely impressive performance by youthful England team in pot greets but of it the 5 one win was overshadowed by racist abuse with Raheem Sterling gesturing to a section of the home supporters after he scored and the FA today condemning what it called abhorrent chanting towards some of the team's players Danny rose seems to have been subjected to the worst treatment but it wasn't confined to the Spurs defender as the 18 year old Chelsea winger Callum Hudson-Odoi e told Middle Eastern broadcaster beIN Sports after he made his full debut when you hear stuff like that from the fans is not right is unacceptable and heard Uefa do it properly because obviously when I went over there are numerous he heard it was seeing someone start of the stuff that we can't just keep your head keep strong and very Uefa's President today called the incident a disaster and the governing body has charged Montenegro with racist behaviour if found guilty the minimum punishment they can expect is a partial stadium closure qualifying is also likely but Troy Townsend football's anti discrimination campaign group kick It out says the time has now come to get tougher is closed in the stadium for a game that is not but be against England were big or expulsion more worth it I'm all for that enough is enough you can't plan this tournament to sort yourself out if referees become aware of racist abuse they have the power to halt or even abandoned matches the England manager Gareth Southgate said he only became aware of the issue towards the end of the game may ask his players if they want to walk off the field in future there is precedent in 2017 Pescara's Sulley Muntari left the pitch during an Italian League game against Calgary because of abuse but in a season in which allegations of racism have crept back into the domestic game Southgate also admitted that English football is not immune from the issue you're listening to the 6 o'clock News on BBC radio 4 the main News so far senior backbench MPs have given details of how parliament for girl about voting for a new way forward for Brexit tomorrow European football's governing body has charged Montenegro with racism after England players were abused during euro Twenty20 qualifying match last night and still to come how Nasser had to cancel a historic spacewalk because it could provide the right suits for female astronauts and the Indiana Jones of the art world tracks down another stolen treasure the Kurdish administration in Syria has called for the establishment of an international court there to try thousands of suspected members of the Islamic State group around 1000 foreign fighters be among those in the Syrian Kurdish detention following the total recapture territory from I.S. along with thousands more foreign women suspected of joining the group and also the children Aleem Maqbool reports from Qamishli in Northern Syria meeting Kurdish officials in Syria their frustration with Western countries is all too clear after all celebrating the capture of the final sliver of the Islamic state group

from the Chilean's we're joined now by two economist Professor Nyeri Woods founding Dean of the Blavatnik school of government and Professor of global economic governance at the University of Oxford is in our Oxford studio and Gerrard lines is in our Tunbridge Wells studio former economic adviser to Boris Johnson when he was Mayor of London now chief economic strategist at that wealth and board member of the Bank of China good morning good morning and deadlines what do you think of the deal I think Boris Johnson still Spa better for the economy than Theresa May's deal I think this is the biggest positive is likely to come in the next stage in terms of trade negotiations but also I think there will be an immediate quick Quinn for the economy in a sense it removes uncertainty we've already seen the financial markets give the thumbs up in the last week with Sterling strengthening I think that same positive sentiment is likely to be seen in terms of a boost business confidence maybe business investment or allow the Chancellor to go ahead and feel empowered to announce an infrastructure boosting the early November budget and stronger £ itself will keep inflation of uncertainty and for a time he does it I think the key thing is the next stage you seek to make a success of leaving the European Union might think Brexit is a great positive for the country and the economy to make a success we need to get 3 things right a domestic economic agenda our relationship with the rest of the world than 90% of global growth this from outside the European Union next two decades and a sense of future relationship with the EU the problem with Theresa May's deal was our future relationship with the EU was going to tie our hands on domestic policy and our relationship with the rest of the world Boris Johnson deal and frees up their so not only about having a good sensible future relationship with the EU that we needed to negotiate the next 15 months it is also about in parrying us and the domestic economy and on the global agenda as well and that's right think the still gives us a lot more room for manoeuvre for first words what do you think Yes well I agree that those are the 3 issues where Britain stands now let's not forget the our politicians have spent the last two years arguing about what kind of bus ticket to buy we haven't even got on the bus yet and it will be a very long bus ride and we don't yet have agreement on what the destination is where is it that we're actually going to get to so when people say we just want this done in Britain has two choices if it's going to get on that but it's got to accept we've got to be honest with that with the people that this will be a very long bus ride but where are we heading I think that but what has really changed since the referendum is the choice of destinations because Britain is now have to decide is it going to be an economy which more or less lines up with the United States standards in things like financial services banking agriculture or is it going to be an economy that more or less lines up with the European Union standards and on things like environment financial services and banking tax and regulation of the big tech companies agriculture and food I think probably most Brits most parliamentarians want to line up with the European Union so this is all to play for now and I think what we've got to now be honest about is that the choice there isn't a third choice It's not as if Britain Ken in today's world economy session an entirely third way Gerrard lines is I mean I can do you agree that there's a choice even if you think the choice should be more America the EU might think Professor Woods has touched on many issues I've talked about myself and I think though her outcome is the wrong one this is not a choice between Britain deciding to follow America as opposed to deciding from the EU but we just need a sense of realism first and foremost the UK is a very imbalanced economy Clearly there are many things we should have done the last 40 years we were in the EU that we didn't do it would be more empowered to do the outside but the same time we need a vision a sense of direction It's about repositioning the UK in a changing group growing global economy and financial services the fears of 3 years ago had effectively been replaced by a sense of reality that the UK is a global financial centre but we do need to compete not only against the York against Singapore in terms of the environment and workers rights UK has been at the forefront of pushing these I think we will now with Parliament responsive to people's votes based art domestic agenda then that will actually make sure we are at the forefront of those clearly in other areas as Professor Wood has touched on their global rules and regulations natural leap 8% of UK firms that sell into the EU market will have resigned you agree with me it will be realistic we've got to be realistic about the fact that to do a free trade agreement with the United with the European Union it takes around at least 5 years if you look at Japan if you look at Canada the other big G7 economies it takes 5 years we need a long transition period for going to be realistic it is not realistic to think that Britain can conclude a free trade agreement in the next

morning campaigners say government proposals to put a statutory duty of care on social media companies will make the UK a world pioneer in protecting children online government is still trying to reach an agreement with Labour on Brexit although no new face-to-face talks have been scheduled and tear gas and stun grenades have been used by elements of the Sudanese military in Khartoum to try to disperse protesters demanding the president's resignation the BBC News read this morning that I speak social media companies could see their services blocks and senior managers held personally liable if the firms breach new statutory duty of care a government white paper published today says companies must take more responsibility for users safety as well as for harmful content that appears on their sites the home Secretary Sajid Javid said tech firms were being forced to clean up their act once and for all the NSPCC said the proposals which are Maggot consultation would make Britain a world pioneer in protecting children online with the details Here's our media editor Amol Rajan in recent years the big technology firms have come under sustained pressure to act as images of self harm child abuse and terrorist propaganda have permeated through social media platforms this long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations but many of the details remain far from clear for the first time oversight of the internet would be interested to a regulator a statutory duty of care to protect users would be enforced with potential for heavy fines to be administered the government has not yet decided whether it will set up a new regulator or trust this work to an existing watchdog a sure sign that hard policy work is just beginning the new rules will apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user generated content or ought to interact with others critics say apply the same rules the company's of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance so entrenching power of big tech Rob Jones is the National crime agency's director for child sex abuse and exploitation he told his people working for social media companies had to take a more active approach to crime was no longer tolerated on the internet flourishing in plain sight it would seem completely irrational normal wouldn't it that if you are running at a technology platform the euro responsible and you felt morally and ethically responsible for was on there and once a duty of care is established the mindset of those that run those platforms I hope changes from talking about bad actors to ignore you know there isn't bad business models which allowed bad actors to flourish with just days to go before Breck Britain is due to leave the EU without a deal Labour is waiting to learn whether the government will put forward proposals which could break the impasse over Brexit yesterday the Prime Minister defended her decision to seek cross-party compromise but today a leading Brexiteer Boris Johnson warned the getting Labour on board could involve what he called a completely unacceptable surrender our political correspondent Vicki young reports Theresa may has said a cross-party compromise is now the only way forward because the DUP and some of her own MPs have refused to back her deal some pro-Brexit Conservatives fear the Prime Minister is preparing to keep Britain in the customs union one of Jeremy Corbyn's key demands communication between the two sides is continuing but little detail has emerged Labour figures believe progress now depends on a concrete offer from the government the former foreign Secretary Boris Johnson writing in the Telegraph as a customs union would mean Britain has no control over its trade policy and it cannot must not and Will not happen on Wednesday Mrs may will go to Brussels for an emergency EU summit she's already requested another short Brexit delay until the end of June but if EU leaders don't think she has a credible plan to get Parliament behind a deal they might refuse or insist on a much lengthier extension to article 50 an outcome which is also opposed by some Brexiteers with just 5 days to go before the UK is due to leave the EU there are still great uncertainty that Mrs May's options and appeared very limited elements of the security forces in Sudan have used tear gas and stun grenades to try to disperse protesters who have been demanding the resignation of President Omar al-Bashir

Nick Robinson which you can get on BBC sounds in the next hour of the programme will be talking to the deputy leader of the Labour party about water future Labour government would do on social media and tech companies which cause harm and two teenagers they want to consider a new regulator would have the power to break them up will also be talking about bird boxes and the of people protested at Stansted to due to be sentenced today you're listening to their Radio 4 Michelle Hussain and John Humphrys of our art of art art It's 7 o'clock on Wednesday the 6th of February the News headlines this morning President Trump has used his delayed state of the Union address who urged Democrats to work with him are refusing to abandon the immigration policy that led to the showdown of the United States government shutdown of the state government a senior Taliban negotiators told the BBC the group does not want to take control of Afghanistan by force and Labour is promising to create a new regulator for the big tech companies to give people control over their personal data and protect children from online harm News is read by Susan Rae in the annual state of the Union address President Trump has made an appeal to the Democrats to co-operate with him for the good of the American people the speech had been delayed by a week because of the row over the funding of a wall along the border with Mexico the stand-off which led to the partial shutdown of the US government Mr. Trump urged Democrats to choose greatness of gridlock and implement what he called a common-sense Proposal that would make America safe our North America correspondent Aleem Maqbool watched the speech in Washington Donald Trump's very statesman-like message to open his address was the US politicians of all persuasions have to work together we must reject the politics of revenge resistance and retribution and British boundless potential of co-operation and compromise and coming good strike inside the house chamber of the President gave his speech the Democratic congresswoman all wearing the white of the suffragette movement as a message there be no rolling back of women's rights under their watch they sat through a list of the president's economic achievements and many grimaced as he took his first big swipe at his opponents an economic miracle was taking place in the United States and the only thing that can stop there are foolish towards politics for we get jealous partisan investigate issues a reference there to Robert Mueller's Russia probe and so after talking in conciliatory terms the president went on to focus on the very thing that caused so much political division in recent weeks immigration and his plans for a border wall for the Democrats have been so vehemently against him building simply put walls work and walls say moved blind he was well over the border wall just led to the longest government shutdown of US history shot dead the president didn't mention in a speech that lasted an hour and a half the Democrat responded by saying that America was made stronger by immigrants not walls military veterans reformed ex-offenders and a young girl who survived cancer among those invited to the capital to hear the President's speech as Mr. Trump presented himself as a leader with an inclusive policy agenda reducing the cost of drugs to eradicating Aids and introducing paid family leave with his assessment of the president's approaches our North America editor Jon Sopel it was as though Donald Trump spent the past few months learning a new language last night trying it out for the first time where once he sought to divide and pick fights last night he tried to be a unifier the politics of grievance percent victory isn't winning for our party it's winning for our country he said and on it went some Democrats in Congress laugh incredulously but the President is responding to a new political reality looking over his shoulder last night with the new Democratic party leader of the house Nancy Pelosi in the audience those Democrats who want to replace him as president in Twenty20 ity with disdain the mid-term elections last November saw Democrats winning in the suburbs winning massively among women the political environment for him has become a lot tougher through the middle the president is seeking to thread is an attempt to broaden support without alienating the Trump base and his tough talk about the border was designed for them but how does he get the funding for that wall that is still his biggest challenge Mr. Trump announced he would be holding a second summit with the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il on the 27th and 28th February in Vietnam

is they can work the other one still refuses to engage in discussions on the future of the country with the Afghan government a major hurdle in reaching a peace agreement Pakistan's government has said Ashya BB the Christian woman cleared of blasphemy is free to leave the country she wants but will be offered protection for the rest of her life if she chooses to stay the foreign minister Shah Mahmoud Qureshi has told today that any country thinking of helping her should pursue what he called quiet diplomacy Theresa may is to hold talks about Brexit with the 5 main parties in Northern Ireland the Democratic unionists have said she must press for changes to the withdrawal agreement with the EU but Sinn Fein will tell the Prime Minister that part of the current plan known as the backstop is the only way to guarantee there will be no checks on the Irish border Mrs may has suggested she is seeking changes to the backstop rather than trying to remove it our Ireland correspondent Chris page reports this is Theresa May's third visit to Northern Ireland and 7 months with a little over 7 weeks to go until the UK due to leave the EU the future of the border with the Irish Republic is still the main sticking point in the Brexit process the two biggest storm parties will give the Prime Minister very different messages about the backstop which is designed to ensure will be no checkpoints on the frontier under any circumstances Sinn Féin has said her plan to ask the EU for legally binding changes is a huge act of but fearful but the DUP says the current backstop proposal is unacceptable the Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar has again ruled out any renegotiation he is travelling to Brussels for talks with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker Mrs may will go there tomorrow Mr. Rudd Kirk will meet with the Northern Ireland parties on Friday man has been stabbed to death in south-west London the victim who's thought to have been 19 was attacked in Battersea last night no-one has been arrested Labour is promising to take tougher action against giant digital companies should gain power in a speech in London the deputy leader Tom Watson will announce measures to protect personal data and prevent children being harmed on online material these will include the creation of a new regulator with the power to break up tech firms is our technology correspondent Rory Cellan-Jones Tom Watson says a decade ago he looked forward to use OLED technology utopia but in his speech today he will say we now find ourselves in a digital dystopia social media is causing mental health problems in young people the online world has become a haven for hate speech and fake news is undermining democracy he says the Root causes market distorted by data monopolies and a future Labour government would create a regulator with the power to break them up if necessary there also be a legal duty of care on companies to protect users especially children and young people from harmful content yesterday the digital Minister Margot James outline plans for new laws to make social media firms remove illegal content so far However the government hasn't talked about breaking companies up the Oscars ceremony will take place without a horse this month for the first time in 30 years the comedian Kevin Hart step down in December after apologising for Hong For the comments he made a decade earlier but time is 9 minutes past 7 the balance of power needs to shift from the big tech companies to their users and a future Labour government will make that happen that's what the deputy leader of the party will say in a speech later today saying that the death of 14 year-old Molly Russell is an example of the harm online content can do the teenager took her own life her family believe content she viewed on Instagram was partly responsible for Tom Watson

Yorker article Mr. movies admitted making women uncomfortable by making advances those were mistakes and I regret them immensely he said while also insisting he always abided by the principle that no represents institutions said NBA's should not be used to stop students from speaking out if they have concerns the Department for education echoed that saying it was unacceptable she used a signed agreement for student complaints and was legislating to stop their misuse after almost two centuries next year's sensors could be the last one ever carried out the UK's national statisticians Sir Ian Diamond was appointed last year said that in the future there could be better and cheaper alternatives to the compulsory survey each household in Britain which takes place every 10 years our home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw reports the UK census provides valuable information about the population which helps the government councils and other organisations plan public services but it's increasingly expensive project for England and Wales alone cost next year will be more than 900 million £ double the amount spent in 2011 Sir Ian Diamond said his officials were conducting research to find out if other data sources could be used instead such as the ordinance survey council tax records in GP lists combined with regular large-scale population surveys the national statistician said it might be possible to replicate the richness of data supplied by the census in a less costly and more timely way Sir Ian said he expected to make a recommendation to the government on the way forward after the research and next year's census had been evaluated one of David Hockney's most famous works the splash has been sold at auction for just over 23 million £ at Sotherby's in London the painting the key image in the history of pop art depicts the moment after a diver hits the water in LA swimming pool prices 8 times higher than when the painting was last sold 14 years ago Thank 9 minutes past 7 as the time a duty of care it sounds such a mild thing reasonable thing but if online companies were made responsible for user generated content well it would be quite a change they say the change that would harm free speech still government is expected to press ahead as we were hearing the news of plans to make Ofcom the broadcasting watchdog responsible for enforcing a new duty on the tech companies the culture Secretary Nicky Morgan outlined how that duty of care might work platforms will have an obligation to comply with the terms and conditions when they say we don't host certain content or we want to protect vulnerable users children for example we will take things down quickly when complaints are made actual what that says is if they don't do that they are potentially a breach of their duty of care and the regulator will the old Satan construct termed the Oceans what you can do about it back in December we spoke to Lucy Alexander whose teenage son Felix killed himself after being bullied online she now campaigns in this part of the cyber-bullying task for shooters big tech needs to be reined in need to use the tech available to them Felix was bullied online predominantly from the age of about 13 nice pays it was a platform that there was no regulation on they all had smartphones at this stage it is very difficult for us as parents to try and find out what was happening to him he had access to all sorts of content that we had no idea what it Mars freedom of speech is all well and good but with that comes responsibility I think they have taken a bit of responsibility for what they publish on their platforms Andy Burrows's head of child safety online policy at the NSPCC is here in the studio morning to you good morning to welcome what the government's doing we do welcome this step the duty of care legislation is something the NSPCC has been campaigning for since 2017 this potentially can be a transformative moved to set out a British model for how we can regulate to protect children online and in turn that can go on and become the global standard for how this should be done under Ofcom the right regular we think Ofcom is the right regulator has the existing blend of regulatory expertise that it can bring to to introducing tackling the problems we see with tech firms crucially as well that will help to ensure that we can get the regulator up and running and taking decisions quickly and there is an urgency here because NSPCC figures have shown that every day since the online Hamas white paper when the government first set out
